replies.bodyText:
From #996 (comment) it is the former, yes.
@bogdandrutu and @trask could you please provide more input on this?
replies.author: thisthat

replies.bodyText: I like the convention of looking for system properties with one.twoThree and looking for the same env var with ONE_TWO_THREE. Since the translation is not reversible (does ONE_TWO_THREE map to one.two.three or oneTwo.three or ...), I think it makes sense to use the system property names in the internal map.
replies.author: trask

timeline.bodyText: common.export?

timeline.bodyText: Use autovalue to avoid writing unnecessary code?
timeline.author: bogdandrutu

timeline.bodyText: It is hard to understand these names, I would propose to prefix all of them with "DEFAULT_"
timeline.author: bogdandrutu

replies.bodyText: I'd also like to have them documented outside of these private fields. Maybe put them in a package-info file?
replies.author: jkwatson

timeline.bodyText: final?
timeline.author: bogdandrutu
bogdandrutu

replies.bodyText:
I'd even prefer completely separating the steps of collection and application of configuration. The builder should just have applyFromConfig and the collection happens separately.
I.e., I propose something like:
// Config is similar to / placeholder for Map<String, String> or Map<String, Object>
final Config cfg = Config.newBuilder()
  .readEnv()
  .readSystemProps()
  .readCommandLine(args)
  .set(MY_KEY, MY_OVERRIDE_VALUE)
  .build();
final BatchSpanProcessor processor = BatchSpanProcessor.newBuilder()
  .applyConfig(cfg)
  .build();
replies.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: If we allowed Map<String, Object> (or stored that in the hypothetical Configuration class) we could even support different representations of complex objects like resources from different sources, e.g. JSON object in JSON, URL/query encoded in envvar, ....
replies.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText:
I liked the proposed API to build the config. "nit: applyConfig -> setConfig" probably better name for a builder.
Also I expect that "readX" methods only apply changes to arguments defined by "X" correct? Does not overwrite all the arguments with default if not defined in the config.
We can also offer a helper Config.loadFromDefaultSources() (we can think of a better name) which essentially allows users to avoid the 5 lines you wrote to build the config.
replies.author: bogdandrutu

timeline.bodyText: Add a comment about the keys are expected for the map.

timeline.bodyText: Add a link to the relevant env vars?

timeline.bodyText: javadoc needed here.

timeline.bodyText: So I feel like this could be re-used by other configuration logic. But of course, lets do that in a follow-up PR ;)

timeline.bodyText: I feel that for env we want all uppercase?

replies.bodyText: was just going to say the same. we should normalize the env vars to uppercase.

timeline.bodyText: For the moment this can be moved to ENV and make it abstract here.
timeline.author: bogdandrutu

timeline.bodyText: If you do what I suggested this can be removed and becomes internal detail for every enum type.
timeline.author: bogdandrutu

timeline.bodyText: Can you specify that it sets only the values that are present, otherwise leaves the value untouched?
timeline.author: bogdandrutu

timeline.bodyText: Iterate over entries not keyset if you need access to the values as well.
timeline.author: bogdandrutu

timeline.bodyText: Do we need to have this public?
timeline.author: bogdandrutu

replies.bodyText: If someone wanted to use this to build config from a parsed yaml/json/xml file, this would be a handy entry point.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: Not really, you cannot extend the enum, so it will support only DOT or ENV for the enum. Also I feel like we should not expose helpers just in case someone needs it (we will suffer maintaining this API). I would suggest to remove it.
replies.author: bogdandrutu

replies.bodyText:
I left it public because I thought that the agent might load the json/xml/yaml file and use this API to set the configuration object.
So the agent will properly create the map with the ENV or DOT naming convention.
replies.author: thisthat

replies.bodyText: In the SIG call, we agreed on supporting Properties as an additional configuration medium. This method can be package visible only.
replies.author: thisthat

timeline.bodyText: We can use auto-value for this as well to remove a lot of variables end ensure no bugs coming from copy-paste.

timeline.bodyText: This document should specify both the env vars, the system properties, and the defaults, I think.
